sections: Rob Kufalk is ‚Äúalways at the mercy of the railroad,‚Äù as his wife Mona puts it. ‚ÄúOur life only functions around the railroad.‚Äù

A longtime conductor for BNSF Railway, Kufalk is virtually always on call. He must be ready to get to work within 90 minutes from when the company says they need him ‚Äî which can happen any time, day or night. The family lives 45 minutes away from the terminal in La Crosse, Wisconsin, that serves as his home base. He spends a lot of time away in hotels in Chicago and Galesburg, Illinois.
Kufalk said the demands on his time have gotten worse over the years, with the industry shedding jobs to cut costs as part of its so-called ‚Äúprecision scheduled railroading‚Äù

. The situation, he said, has become unbearable since BNSF implemented a new points-based attendance policy, under which employees can be disciplined or fired for missing a call to come into work or taking an unplanned day off.

‚ÄúThey want us available for duty 95 percent of the time now ‚Äî 24/7/365,‚Äù said Kufalk. ‚ÄúI try to plan for doctor‚Äôs appointments and other things and it‚Äôs almost impossible. Sometimes you just have to lay off and take the hit on the points.‚Äù

The lack of paid sick time afforded to workers was at the center of the high-stakes labor dispute between unions and giant railroad companies that came to a head last week. Through more than three years of contract negotiations, the railroads flatly refused to budge and give workers any paid sick days. The companies knew they didn‚Äôt really have to negotiate, because politicians in Washington wouldn‚Äôt risk allowing rail workers to strike and slow shipments ‚Äî especially now during the holiday season ‚Äî at an estimated cost to the economy of $2 billion per day.

President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration first intervened in the labor dispute this summer, convening an emergency board to broker a recommended deal that included just one paid sick day for rail workers. Last week, at Biden‚Äôs urging, Congress passed a law to block a strike and impose the administration‚Äôs labor deal over workers‚Äô objections. A measure offered by progressives to add seven sick days to the deal won some Republican support but still failed in the corporate-controlled Senate.

But as the story of Kufalk and his family demonstrates, the number of sick days granted to rail workers ‚Äî and the way politicians just helped railroad barons railroad them ‚Äî isn‚Äôt just some political issue. The matter strikes at the systematic devaluing of the people who literally keep the country rolling, who have seen their benefits deteriorate and their schedules get far more extreme as railroad companies have decimated their workforce to juice corporate profits and executives‚Äô payouts.

Kufalk wishes the lawmakers who voted down the sick leave proposal last week would "take the time to learn more about the railroad lifestyle," in order to balance what's best for businesses and the economy with the needs of rail workers who sacrifice to make the economy run. If lawmakers spent some time working on the railroads, Kufalk wagers, "they‚Äôd be more than happy to go back home to Congress.‚Äù

He and Mona both said they voted for Biden in the 2020 presidential campaign based on his promises to be pro-labor. Kufalk clarified he would never have considered voting for Trump; he voted for Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) in the Democratic primary (‚ÄúShe‚Äôs my girl‚Äù), while Mona said she voted for Sen. Bernie Sanders (Ind-Vt.).
But now Kufalk, who said he‚Äôs voted to strike several times throughout the contract negotiation process, told
after the Senate vote that he felt ‚Äúbetrayed‚Äù by those he helped put in power.
‚Äú[Biden] lost a big chance to set himself apart from the Republicans,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a big failure on his part.‚Äù
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs So Many Things We Can‚Äôt Do‚Äù
A former law enforcement officer and dairy farmer before that, Kufalk first got hired by BNSF, the country‚Äôs
freight railroad, in Alliance, Nebraska, working on trains that mostly hauled coal. Now, he works as a conductor out of Wisconsin.

‚ÄúWe haul anything and everything,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIntermodal, mixed freight, and commodities, military trains, vehicle trains ‚Äî you name it. If it‚Äôs something that goes on a rail car, at some point or another, I‚Äôve probably been on a train with it.‚Äù

As for the ins and outs of the job, Kufalk said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm responsible for the paperwork for the train, doing any work that‚Äôs associated with the train like set-ups, pickups, or if there‚Äôs any troubles. If the train breaks in two or goes into [an] emergency because an air hose separates or anything like that, I‚Äôm responsible for putting it back together.‚Äù
His duties include overseeing train makeup and compliance, and placement of cars to ensure weight is distributed properly.
His duties include overseeing train makeup and compliance, and placement of cars to ensure weight is distributed properly.

The job involves lots of walking, often on unsteady surfaces in all kinds of weather conditions, followed by long periods of waiting around. After shifts that last up to 12 hours, Kufalk said he‚Äôs either brought back to his home terminal or to a motel, where he then takes a 10.5 hour rest period.
The rest periods often occur and end at odd times, which can make it difficult to find food. So Kufalk usually travels with a large, insulated lunch container and enough food to get through a trip.
The demands on Kufalk‚Äôs time and the unpredictable nature of his schedule means he and Mona lead separate lives.

‚ÄúMy life is separate from Rob,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI love him so much, and I want to do things with him. We can‚Äôt. We don‚Äôt have a life where we have nights out with friends. We can‚Äôt join a bowling league. There‚Äôs so many things we can‚Äôt do. Our grandsons play hockey. We‚Äôve not been to a hockey game for our grandsons.‚Äù
Over time, Kufalk has seen his benefits get worse as part of a broader shift in how management treats the workers.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never complained about the pay,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhen I first started out, we had excellent health insurance. We didn‚Äôt have to pay any monthly subsidies for it or anything.‚Äù He noted that, in 2008, he only had to pay $20 after getting carpal tunnel surgery done on both wrists, adding: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been downhill from there.‚Äù
Now, Kufalk said he‚Äôs paying about $250 each month for a family insurance plan that also covers his wife, while ‚Äúa surgery ends up costing around $4,000 or $5,000 out of pocket.‚Äù
Kufalk said the railroad companies used to show more gratitude for workers ‚Äî regularly providing hot meals, particularly on holidays, and giving them gift cards they could use at the BNSF store.

‚ÄúAll that stuff‚Äôs gone by the wayside,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúLast year, I was down in Galesburg, Illinois, for Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year‚Äôs Eve. And there‚Äôs nothing at the hotel saying, ‚ÄòCome to the depot, we have food there for you‚Äô... That was how much gratification there was to show us thanks for working on holidays.‚Äù

Kufalk said it‚Äôs part of an increasingly ‚Äúanti-labor mindset‚Äù from BNSF management. ‚ÄúThe CEOs need to remember that if it wasn‚Äôt for us out there, humping the trains down the rails, they wouldn‚Äôt be having their multimillion-dollar salaries,‚Äù he added.
Asked about Warren Buffett ‚Äî the billionaire chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, which owns BNSF ‚Äî Kufalk didn‚Äôt hold back.
‚ÄúI think our dear Uncle Warren is nothing but a money-grubbing pig,‚Äù said Kufalk. Given BNSF's

, he argued, "[Buffett] could say, ‚ÄòI want all my employees [to have] paid 100 percent health insurance, and a very handsome 401(k) and retirement pension, and I want it all paid for,‚Äô and it wouldn‚Äôt cost him a dime. He would have the happiest employees ever, and the most productive, and he would reap more benefits, but he‚Äôll never do that. Instead, he‚Äôs more worried about where his next money‚Äôs coming from, like Scrooge McDuck.‚Äù
Across the railroad industry, companies have made devaluing labor and reducing their workforce a core part of their business model, in order to maximize profits and enrich shareholders.
,‚Äù a theory pioneered in the 1990s, railroad companies have gutted their head counts while vastly increasing the average length of trains in order to limit their ‚Äú
,‚Äù or how much they spend running the railroads.
‚ÄúWe have a lot of trains now that are right around that top 10,000-foot length,‚Äù Kufalk said, explaining that precision scheduled railroading effectively means workers ‚Äúdoing more with less.‚Äù
Over the past six years, large U.S. freight rail companies

The substantially smaller workforce has meant less maintenance and dirtier cars, according to Kufalk. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre running with more cracked windshields, heaters that aren‚Äôt necessarily working right, we‚Äôre having more breakdowns than what we used to have,‚Äù he said.

It also means slower shipments. ‚ÄúOn weekends now, we are tying trains down on the main line because there‚Äôs not enough crews to take to the next destination,‚Äù said Kufalk. ‚ÄúThat exacerbates the problem, because then they have to call a bunch of crews right away when they‚Äôre rested to go and get those trains moving again. It just makes the crew shortage even worse.‚Äù

The drive to reduce worker numbers has culminated in onerous attendance policies like the new points-based system from BNSF, which requires workers to be available around-the-clock if and when management needs them.

, workers start with 30 points and are docked points if they fail to respond to a call from management, or if they need to take an unscheduled day off. Losing too many points can mean disciplinary action or firing.

The BNSF policy has led to mass resignations ‚Äî with the situation getting so bad that the company has been offering $10,000 bonuses to employees to defer their retirements for six months, according to Kufalk.
‚ÄúThe railroads are trying to hire people, but they can‚Äôt keep the people they‚Äôre hiring,‚Äù he said.
Kufalk was scheduled to retire in December. He agreed to take a bonus and will work now through April next year.
‚ÄúI‚Äôll Take A Hit On The Points‚Äù

Railroad companies dragged out negotiations over a new contract with unions for more than three years, refusing to offer workers any paid sick time, even amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Employees currently have little choice but to work while sick ‚Äî often in close, confined quarters.
that workers have ample vacation time, despite not having paid sick days.
Kufalk, meanwhile, noted that in his 17th year with BNSF, he currently has four weeks of vacation ‚Äî a generous amount by American
‚Äî but the company determines when he can use most of this time off. As a result, it‚Äôs still difficult to schedule visits to the doctor or dentist, he said.

The lack of paid sick time has been a key sticking point in negotiations between unions and the railroads. In the recent contract negotiations, unions initially pushed the railroads to grant workers as many as
. The companies held firm, refusing to pay any sick time at all.
Under the terms of the deal negotiated between Biden‚Äôs emergency board, railroad companies, and unions, workers are set to get a single paid sick day a year.

At Biden‚Äôs urging, Congress passed legislation last week to impose his deal over the objections of workers who were ready to go on strike. The Senate failed to pass an amendment offered by Sanders and backed by Warren that would have given railroad workers seven paid sick days. They will only get one.

Next year, Kufalk will retire with an extra bonus. He and Mona are planning to sell their house and move somewhere on the water. For the moment, he‚Äôs nearly always on call, but he‚Äôs not missing any more important days with his family.

Kufalk said he ‚Äúrefused to go to work this Thanksgiving,‚Äù and used his last remaining vacation day for the year. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to be working Christmas either,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll take a hit on the points. I‚Äôm not going to give them the satisfaction.‚Äù
This weekend, Mona said, Kufalk will take a point deduction so the family can ‚Äî for the first time ‚Äî watch their grandkids play in a hockey tournament.
‚ÄúWhat are they going to do ‚Äî fire him?‚Äù she said.
